title-group.article-title: Managerial Control and Executive Compensation in the 1930s: A Reexamination

abstract.p: This article reexamines an earlier empirical study by Stigler and Friedland [14] on the relationship between stockholder control and executive compensation for a sample of firms in the 1930s. They find no significant empirical relation between these two variables, casting some doubt on the relevance on the Berle and Mean thesis. After controlling for the profitability of the firm and the competitiveness of the product market, this study finds that a higher degree of stockholder control significantly lowers executive remuneration, ceteris paribus. This result may provide some empirical support for the Berle and Mean thesis concerning the separation of ownership and control.
